Name: Schaum's Outline of Quantum Mechanics, Second Edition (Schaum's Outline Series)

ReviewList.Text: This edition cleans up alot of the typos in the previous version and also cleans up the format as well.  As such, it makes a previously useful but carelessely edited book very wortwhile.  Importantly, this book should be used as an adjunct to a major textbook (I used Shankar, for example), and not as the primary learning tool itself.  However, if used in this fashion, it can provide some very concise and useful review.  The problems are very useful and in fact logically help build up the theoretical foundation of the subject.  For the price, I certainly think this second edition is worth it.

I find that Schaums books range from ones that can be used almost as textbooks, to those which are very, very abbreviated and possibly useful as an aide-memoire for those familiar with the material. If the latter is what you are looking for, go ahead. I just wanted a brief overview to put into perspective some concepts that I have read about in my mathematics and other study, and this didn't really do the job. I think its appeal is limited, admittedly though there are not a lot of options for introductory but reasonably rigorous material.
The book is detailed and the answers appear to be correct, but there are lots of typos in the text and in the formulae.  This volume was not carefully proofread.

Title says it all. The only problem with the kindle version is the size of the equations. Since there's no way to zoom in on the Kindle, it makes progress through the book much slower since you have to lean way in to see the parts you actually care about.
After working through a more advanced text I was happy to find one which gets to the point without unnecessary abstraction.  I wish it contained some field theory, but that's not what it is about.
I found this to be very helpful in my coursework. The explanations were plentiful, etc. I may write more later. Could use more 'review' or essential problems.
Good reference if you've already learned the material formally.  Some notational differences from what I'm used to, but still very usable.

I used this book to help with an intro to QM class, was a great help answered some questions that were tough..... all in all it was great for a helper and for the money was good.  My professor even asked where i got it so he could have some of his other students get it.
Mathematical formulae displayed in very short font size. Difficult to read unless expanded with finger tips which turns them out of context.

This is the missing link for understanding introductory Quantum Mechanics problems. Multiple examples of the schrodinger equation are explored in various potential wells / tunneling examples. Even and Odd equations are not covered thoroughly. The hamiltonian operator is explained along with an overview of commonly used mathematical operations.  This book carries through to higher level classes like quantum field theory and scatter theory .

Use this book with caution.  I have little knowledge of Quantum Mechanics and I'm not using any other textbook in conjunction with Schaum's.  The solutions are good and are worked out well.  But I have to work backwards to figure out the solutions with Internet searches.  However, as a self-study student, this methodology is a good way to learn the material.  It's a slow method, but QM is very complex and boring.  Anything to make it interesting is a plus!
My quantum class concentrates on qubits and intuitive quantum mechanics which is not the same focus as this problem solving manual.
